awd_titl_txt: Using Self-Assembled Cyclic and Linear Block Copolymer Blends as Templates for Sub-10 nm Soft Lithography
awd_abstract_narration:
Thanks to advancements in the microelectronics industry over the past fifty years, today's smart phones are more powerful and less expensive than the best supercomputers of the 1970's and 1980's. These technologies impact nearly every facet of life - from entertainment and personal communication to healthcare and national defense. Currently, computer chip manufacturing uses lasers to pattern ever-smaller features to make faster processors and create higher density data storage. However, the cost of patterning using this approach is rising faster than the benefits afforded by smaller features, necessitating the development of new manufacturing approaches to advance the field and maintain U.S. status as a world leader in advanced manufacturing. This grant supports fundamental research into an alternative patterning method that uses block copolymers, a type of rubbery plastic that naturally forms nanoscale patterns through a process called self-assembly. The research generates the knowledge necessary to transform the manufacture of next-generation nanoelectronics that can be incorporated into communication devices, security technologies, health monitors, and disease treatments. These advances contribute to national prosperity, health and security. This project brings together an interdisciplinary team of researchers with expertise in molecular simulations and experimental materials synthesis to train a diverse cohort of high school, undergraduate, and doctoral students that will drive innovation in advanced materials manufacturing.

Block copolymer self-assembly offers a direct manufacturing route to nanostructure formation that eliminates the need for more complex, time-consuming, and costly laser-based patterning methods. This project investigates the phase behavior of strongly segregated cyclic block copolymers, which show promise for accessing sub-10 nm feature sizes and stabilizing polymer thin films against dewetting. The project uses complementary experimental and computational approaches to not only compare cyclic block copolymers to linear analogues but also to evaluate nanostructure quality in cyclic/linear block copolymer blends as templates for nanolithography. To realize manufacturing scalability of this approach, two critical challenges are addressed: First, using small quantities of cyclic block copolymer as a structure-directing and film-stabilizing agent to achieve target lithographic domain sizes while minimizing the amount of specialty cyclic block copolymer. Second, if shorter reaction times and less dilute solution conditions are used in the synthesis of cyclic molecules to improve yield, understanding what linear impurities are generated and how do they impact self-assembly. Throughout the project, insight into the thermodynamic origin of the structures formed are derived from molecular simulations to guide and optimize experimental design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Among the next generation of technologies, we expect medical diagnostic devices that are more accurate and portable; electronic devices that are faster, smaller, and capable of storing more information; and energy sources that are cleaner without sacrificing capacity or power. To realize these advances, the semiconductor industry needs new lithography methods that will enable them to go from "micro" fabrication to "nano" fabrication. Block copolymers (BCPs), the types of molecules that make up many plastics, rubbers, and adhesives, also exhibit a nano-scale structure that can address the challenges associated with patterning smaller features. Because BCPs consist of two types of polymers, etching only one of the polymers enables the nano-scale polymer pattern to be transferred to a silicon wafer for semiconductor chip manufacturing. If the molecular structure of the BCP is changed from linear (like an un-clasped necklace) to cyclic (like a clasped necklace), the feature size can be decreased theoretically by up to 40%.  In this research project, Professors Julie Albert and Hank Ashbaugh combined laboratory experiments and molecular simulations to evaluate the suitability of cyclic BCPs to meet the semiconductor industry's need for next-generation nanolithography.

The requirements for block-copolymer based nanolithography include defect-free, sub-10 nm features, low interfacial width (sharp boundaries) between phases, formation of nanostructures at low molecular weights (short polymers), and vertical orientation of nanostructures on a silicon wafer (to create line or do patterns). Because cyclic BCPs proved to be incredibly challenging to synthesize in the lab, the project focused on validating molecular simulations against laboratory data from the scientific literature and then using these simulations to answer the question, "Can cyclic BCPs meet the needs for next-generation nanolithography?" Specifically, simulation data combined with revisions to polymer theory showed that the reduction in feature sizes achievable by molecular cyclization is physically limited to approximately 20% for short polymers; the absolute interfacial width of a self-assembled cyclic BCP is less than that of its linear analogue, but as a fraction of the feature size it is larger (i.e., if the same size pattern was created using a cyclic BCP and a linear BCP, the cyclic BCP pattern would appear blurrier); although cyclic BCP feature size is insensitive to linear BCP impurities that may be present due to an imperfect synthesis, the minimum molecular weight needed to form nanostructures increases slightly if impurities are present; and finally, cyclic BCPs are more sensitive than linear BCPs to surface effects that lead to horizontal rather than vertical lamellar orientation. These results show that although cyclic BCPs can meet the needs for next-generation nanolithography, alternative strategies may be more easily executed and offer better opportunities for investment of resources in the future.


Last Modified: 06/23/2023
Modified by: Julie N Albert

Image
  • Simulations of linear and cyclic block copolymers showing molecule structures, nano-scale feature size comparison, ordered vs disordered, and vertical vs horizonal orientation.
    Julie Albert
    Copyrighted
    Julie N Albert
    Linear vs Cyclic Block Copolymers
